articles.headline: Afghans Demand That U.S. Admit Military Errors
articles.snippet: Afghan officials said a long-term security pact could be reached with the United States if President Obama acknowledged military mistakes and vowed not to repeat them.
articles.abstract: Afghan officials said a long-term security pact could be reached with the United States if President Obama acknowledged military mistakes and vowed not to repeat them.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Months of fraught negotiations and public posturing over how a long-term American military force could remain in Afghanistan have suddenly come down to a demand for a single personal gesture: a display of contrition by President Obama for military mistakes that have hurt Afghans.

articles.headline: Perks Ease Way in Health Plans for Lawmakers
articles.snippet: While millions of Americans struggle with the federal insurance exchange, members of Congress and their aides have all sorts of assistance to help them parse their options and enroll.
articles.abstract: While millions of Americans struggle with the federal insurance exchange, members of Congress and their aides have all sorts of assistance to help them parse their options and enroll.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress like to boast that they will have the same health care enrollment experience as constituents struggling with the balky federal website, because the law they wrote forced lawmakers to get coverage from the new insurance exchanges.

articles.headline: In Extracting Deal From JPMorgan, U.S. Aimed for Bottom Line
articles.snippet: The case against JPMorgan may set a precedent for cases against other major banks and industries like health care, where fines have been growing.
articles.abstract: The case against JPMorgan may set a precedent for cases against other major banks and industries like health care, where fines have been growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:44 p.m. | When Tony West arrived in a Justice Department conference room to put the finishing touches on a lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase, he saw a familiar number flash on his cellphone.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Unavoidable Answer for the Problem of Climate Change
articles.snippet: Opponents call attention to the dire risks of nuclear energy, but in the push to reduce reliance on fossil fuels, it may be the world’s best shot.
articles.abstract: Opponents call attention to the dire risks of nuclear energy, but in the push to reduce reliance on fossil fuels, it may be the world’s best shot.
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan’s announcement last week that it would not meet its promise to sharply reduce its carbon emissions met a chorus of disapproval from around the world.

articles.headline: G’Day From Bushwick
articles.snippet: An Australian property trust is buying homes in the borough and renovating them for rental, part of a larger trend across the United States. Critics say first-time home buyers are getting crowded out.
articles.abstract: An Australian property trust is buying homes in the borough and renovating them for rental, part of a larger trend across the United States. Critics say first-time home buyers are getting crowded out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing in the dining room of the early 1900s-era brick rowhouse, deep in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn with not a frozen yogurt shop or Starbucks to be found, Alan Dixon, an investor from Australia, struggled to tally the houses he had bought in the area over the last year.

articles.headline: You Plan Your Retirement, Then You Get the Health Bill
articles.snippet: The share of medical costs shouldered by retirees is growing, highlighting the need to save a lot more now.
articles.abstract: The share of medical costs shouldered by retirees is growing, highlighting the need to save a lot more now.
articles.lead_paragraph: JEFF STRACK, a 61-year-old sales manager in Charlotte, N.C., enjoys his work and is in good health. But the prospect of paying for health costs after he retires weighs on him.

articles.headline: How Doctors Die: Showing Others the Way
articles.snippet: One way that doctors stand out from the general population is in advance planning for the end of life, something that is gradually finding acceptance.
articles.abstract: One way that doctors stand out from the general population is in advance planning for the end of life, something that is gradually finding acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRAVE. You hear that word a lot when people are sick. It’s all about the fight, the survival instinct, the courage. But when Dr. Elizabeth D. McKinley’s family and friends talk about bravery, it is not so much about the way Dr. McKinley, a 53-year-old internist from Cleveland, battled breast cancer for 17 years. It is about the courage she has shown in doing something so few of us are able to do: stop fighting.

articles.headline: As Trader’s Trial Begins, Name of One Insider Stands Out
articles.snippet: Information that came from a source at Dell’s headquarters led to insider trading charges against eight people, including Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC trader whose trial began Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Information that came from a source at Dell’s headquarters led to insider trading charges against eight people, including Michael S. Steinberg, a former SAC trader whose trial began Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his cubicle at Dell’s headquarters in Round Rock, Tex., Rob Ray shared insights about the computer maker that ricocheted across the country, reaching a trust company in California, a mutual fund in Manhattan and hedge funds in New York and Connecticut.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Ben Protess

articles.headline: A Municipal Bankruptcy May Create a Template
articles.snippet: Jefferson County, Ala., will ask a federal court on Wednesday to approve its plan for exiting bankruptcy, including court oversight for a period of 40 years.
articles.abstract: Jefferson County, Ala., will ask a federal court on Wednesday to approve its plan for exiting bankruptcy, including court oversight for a period of 40 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jefferson County, Ala., which just became the first municipality to tap the public bond markets while bankrupt, will go to court on Wednesday to seek approval for its plan to exit bankruptcy by the end of this year.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Settlement Offers Look Into Mortgage Machine
articles.snippet: After months of wrangling, the bank agreed to a statement of facts with the government that provides new details into how it assembled mortgage securities sold from 2005 through 2008.
articles.abstract: After months of wrangling, the bank agreed to a statement of facts with the government that provides new details into how it assembled mortgage securities sold from 2005 through 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and the Justice Department reached a record $13 billion settlement on Tuesday, wrapping up a series of state and federal investigations that offer a rare glimpse into Wall Street’s mortgage machine before the financial crisis, when it churned out billions of dollars in securities that later imploded.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: In Places Like North St. Louis, Gunfire Still Rules the Night
articles.snippet: Residents of areas like North St. Louis, where drugs, poverty and gunfire beget a cycle of violence, scoff when they hear officials declare that their cities are safer.
articles.abstract: Residents of areas like North St. Louis, where drugs, poverty and gunfire beget a cycle of violence, scoff when they hear officials declare that their cities are safer.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The unmistakable pop of a gunshot ricocheted through the park in the humid air, and Montez Wayne could only hope that the bullet did not have his name on it. He sprang from his seat beneath a sprawling bald cypress, ready to make his move.

articles.headline: Toyota Shows Off Fuel-Cell Automobile
articles.snippet: The car, which Toyota calls the FCV concept car, was one of several fuel-cell vehicles expected to be introduced soon, including models from Honda and Hyundai.
articles.abstract: The car, which Toyota calls the FCV concept car, was one of several fuel-cell vehicles expected to be introduced soon, including models from Honda and Hyundai.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hydrogen-powered cars are finally being readied for their Prius moment — at least, that is what promoters of the environmentally friendly technology hope.

articles.headline: Cost Aside, JPMorgan May Have a Good Deal
articles.snippet: The $13 billion figure reached with the Justice Department may represent political theater as much as a real attempt to right wrongs.
articles.abstract: The $13 billion figure reached with the Justice Department may represent political theater as much as a real attempt to right wrongs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase on Tuesday agreed to a mortgage settlement that will cost the bank $13 billion, a large number that will bolster the government’s claims that justice was done.
